title: Fully vaccinated Saint John councillor tests positive for COVID-19 | CBC News
description: A Saint John city councillor has tested positive for COVID-19.

title: India delivers 1 billion COVID-19 vaccine doses as health officials hope worst of pandemic has passed | CBC News
description: India has administered 1 billion doses of COVID-19 vaccine, officials said Thursday, passing a milestone for the South Asian country where the delta variant fuelled its first crushing surge earlier this year.

title: ICU capacity in Yellowknife pushed to the limit by COVID-19 cases | CBC News
description: Health Minister Julie Green said on Monday that Stanton Territorial Hospital’s six ICU beds 'have been taken up by people who are sick with COVID[-19].'

title: Alberta brings back contact tracing schools as COVID-19 cases continue to surge
description: Alberta reintroduces contact tracing and isolation protocols for schools, and introduces more testing, as COVID-19 continues to rip through the province, including unvaccinated children.

title: COVID-19 Questions and Answers
description: Dr. Brian Conway of the Vancouver Infectious Diseases Centre considers viewer questions about vaccines and more, on The Rundown with host Carole MacNeil

title: 'Reasonable' to consider lifting COVID-19 restrictions, but caution still key: Dr. Hsiu-Li Wang | CBC News
description: The region’s medical officer of health says now is a “reasonable time” for the provincial government to look at further lifting COVID-19 restrictions. Still, Dr. Hsiu-Li Wang said people must continue to be careful.

title: COVID-19 cases decline nationally for the first time in months
description: The Public Health Agency of Canada revealed new modelling that shows that for the country as a whole, the fourth wave is receding. But those gains could be fragile.

title: Everything you need to know about COVID-19 in Alberta on Saturday, Oct. 2 | CBC News
description: The Alberta government rolled out a watermarked vaccine passport and QR codes Friday.

title: COVID-19 detection at N.W.T. Legislature delays public inquiry into MLA's conduct | CBC News
description: Day five of MLA Steve Norn's public inquiry was cut short Friday. A positive case of COVID-19 was detected at the Legislative Assembly, forcing the technical team, court clerk and interpreter to be sent home and arrange for testing. The hearing will resume on Friday Oct. 15, 2021.

title: Manitobans exempt from COVID-19 vaccine to receive same cards as fully vaccinated | CBC News
description: The Manitoba government has finalized its process for receiving and evaluating requests for medical exemptions from its proof of COVID-19 vaccination requirements.

title: N.B. COVID-19 roundup: Free rapid tests for home use expands province-wide, 2 more deaths | CBC News
description: Free rapid test kits will be available to the public at large across New Brunswick starting Monday, Public Health announced Friday, as the province recorded two more COVID-related deaths and 87 new cases of COVID-19.

title: Global pact forged to drastically cut oil production to contain price crash | CBC News
description: The OPEC cartel and other oil producers agreed Sunday to cut crude production by at least a tenth of global supply — an unprecedented move to stabilize the market, according to several energy officials who participated in the talks.

title: 158 Albertans with COVID-19 reported their illness to province's multimillion-dollar app | CBC News
description: The Alberta government will spend $4.3 million by year’s end on a contact tracing phone application that has notified 1,500 users they may have been exposed to COVID-19.

title: B.C. records 749 new cases of COVID-19 and 9 more deaths | CBC News
description: B.C. health officials announced 749 new cases of COVID-19 and nine more deaths on Thursday.

title: N.W.T. chief public health officer, medical director, to give COVID-19 update | CBC News
description: Dr. AnneMarie Pegg, the territory's medical director, and Dr. Kami Kandola, the N.W.T.'s chief public health officer, will hold a media briefing at 2 p.m. Tuesday. CBC will carry it live.

title: COVID-19 detected in Rankin Inlet, Nunavut, wastewater | CBC News
description: Traces of COVID-19 have been detected in Rankin Inlet, Nunavut's wastewater. The territory's acting chief public health officer said that “the unexpected signals could mean people with COVID-19 are in the community or recently travelled through."

title: Liberals, NDP reach deal on sick leave, avoiding immediate election
description: NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh says the Liberal government is willing to boost the number of people who can access sick days, clearing the way for New Democrats to support the throne speech and bypass an immediate fall election.

title: COVID-19 in Sask.: 10 deaths, 242 new cases, record hospitalizations | CBC News
description: New cases have dropped sharply, but a record number of people are in hospital today with COVID-19.

title: Ingredients in COVID-19 vaccines
description: Virologist Jason Kindrachuk says there are no concerns about dangerous ingredients in COVID-19 vaccines and they are safe.

title: This St. Catharines woman says her entire family got COVID-19 from school | CBC News
description: A St. Catharines woman said her family is still reeling after they got infected with COVID-19 in the first week of school.

description: More workplaces, including airlines and the federal government, have made COVID-19 vaccines mandatory and it’s creating division between workplace safety and employment for both unions and employees.

title: Restaurant defying COVID-19 health order closure facing daily $100 fine | CBC News
description: Despite having its business licence suspended for not checking patron's vaccine cards, Rolly's Restaurant in Hope, B.C., was open for business Thursday night.

title: Ontario sees 328 new COVID-19 cases as province finalizes plan to vaccinate 5 to 11 year olds | CBC News
description: Ontario reported 328 new cases of COVID-19 on Tuesday, as Health Minister Christine Elliott made assurances that the province will be "ready to go" if vaccines become available for children in Canada.

description: Newfoundland and Labrador's Department of Health reported eight new cases and another COVID-19-related death on Friday — the 11th due to the virus in the province since the pandemic began.

title: Pfizer submits preliminary data to Health Canada for kids' COVID-19 vaccine | CBC News
description: Pfizer and its partner BioNTech have submitted preliminary data from their trial for a COVID-19 shot for kids to Health Canada earlier than expected, the department confirmed Saturday.

title: Key COVID-19 numbers in the Ottawa area today | CBC News
description: Ottawa Public Health (OPH) reported 41 more COVID-19 cases Wednesday.

title: Why some health-care workers are living apart from their families

title: Meet a Wheel-Trans driver volunteering to help customers with mobility issues get to hospitals and testing facilities
description: Wheel-Trans driver John Begg said with everything going on, he's 'here to help.'

title: New bylaw could cost Torontonians up to $5K if they're caught standing too close

description: First Nation communities in the province’s north have significantly higher active case and death counts than the rest of Saskatchewan, according to population and provincial COVID-19 data.

title: Key COVID-19 numbers in the Ottawa area today | CBC News
description: Ottawa Public Health (OPH) reported 48 new COVID-19 cases Monday and the city is now up to 83 per cent of its eligible population that is fully vaccinated.

description: Ottawa Public Health (OPH) reported 16 more COVID-19 cases Tuesday. The region has its first health unit with 90 per cent of eligible residents fully vaccinated.

title: 306 COVID-19 cases, 2 deaths reported over 3 days in Manitoba | CBC News
description: Manitoba public health officials report 306 new COVID-19 cases and two deaths over three days, a provincial news release issued on Monday says.

description: An "imbalanced" group of experts and with China's resistance to co-operate means the World Health Organization's new panel is leaving some experts dubious it will determine the origin of COVID-19.

description: Leisha Toory is a political science major at Memorial University. She lives in St. John's.

title: Manitoba reports 78 new COVID-19 cases Friday, 115 Thursday, no new deaths | CBC News
description: Friday's update is the first since Wednesday, due to the observation of the National Day for Truth and Reconciliation on Thursday.

title: Key COVID-19 numbers in the Ottawa area today | CBC News
description: Ottawa Public Health (OPH) reported 55 more COVID-19 cases Thursday and the death of a woman in her 80s.

description: COVID-19 has been detected in the wastewater in Fort Simpson, N.W.T. The Office of the Chief Public Health Officer is directing anyone in Fort Simpson with symptoms to isolate and arrange for testing.

title: N.W.T. reports record number of COVID-19 cases in territory with 378 | CBC News
description: A record number of COVID-19 cases was reported in the Northwest Territories Tuesday. The Office of the Chief Public Health Officer (OCPHO) said in a news release there are 378 cases across the N.W.T. It's an increase from the previous record of 341 reported cases Friday, and 340 reported on Monday.

description: Here's CBC Ottawa's latest roundup of key updates during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: COVID-19 booster shots not needed for most people yet, says specialist
description: Canadians who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 might see longer immunity if their shots were spaced further apart than recommended by the vaccine makers, says Dr. Matthew Oughton, an infectious diseases specialist in Montreal who said most people don't need booster shots at this time. (Evan Mitsui/CBC)

Gavin Newsom ordered the first statewide stay-at-home order in the U.S. during the early days of the pandemic.

description: September was arguably Alberta's worst month of the COVID-19 pandemic, data suggests. More Albertans tested positive than in any month prior, and records for hospital and ICU admissions were set. September was also the deadliest month since the second wave. Experts look at what could come next.

description: Mobile vaccination clinics still have a vital role to play when it comes to getting more Albertans vaccinated against COVID-19.

description: The Toronto International Film Festival is reporting a case of COVID-19 in an audience member who attended press and industry screenings.

description: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention advisory panel could vote on the use of a third shot of Pfizer-BioNTech's COVID-19 vaccine on Thursday, an agency official said while kicking off the two-day panel discussion on Wednesday.

And the lessons could apply to public health, too. Medical columnist Dr. Raj Bhardwaj joined CBC Calgary’s Rob Brown to talk about that.

Instead of business as usual, he turned his five refrigerated gourmet coffee trucks into mobile vaccination clinics, volunteering his time and equipment to help the community.

description: A Saskatchewan woman who was given the option of working from home now realizes how wrong she was after losing her husband to COVID-19.

title: 26 new COVID-19 cases in the London area Wednesday, second vaccine doses ramp up | CBC News
description: The Middlesex-London Health Unit is reporting 26 new cases of COVID-19 on Wednesday and no deaths. The health unit has outlined expanded eligibility for second doses of COVID vaccines.

title: Health-care overload due to COVID-19 a concern in Canada, expert says
description: Ontario is already experiencing health-care overload due to the COVID-19 pandemic, according to infectious diseases specialist Dr. Zain Chagla, and other provinces are headed in that direction.

title: London region reports 124 COVID-19 cases over the weekend | CBC News
description: The Middlesex-London Health Unit (MLHU) reported 78 new COVID-19 cases on Sunday, the highest single-day increase in the region since Jan. 20. The new cases came on the heels of another day of double-digit figures. On Saturday, the health unit logged 46 new cases and one new COVID-related death.

title: Nova Scotians heed the call to get tested for Covid-19
description: With the recent spike in new COVID-19 cases and variants on the rise, Nova Scotians responded in droves to the call to get tested. Colleen Jones has the story.

title: Study suggests vaccines may improve symptoms for some COVID-19 long-haulers | CBC News
description: Emerging research suggests vaccines may reduce symptoms for some of those suffering from “long COVID,” where health concerns persist for months after the infectious stage of the illness has passed.

title: N.W.T.'s COVID-19 secretariat apologizes after self-isolating travellers' info breached | CBC News
description: A number of travellers recently self-isolating in Yellowknife had their email addresses revealed in an 'unauthorized disclosure of personal information,' according to a letter sent by the territory's Health department.

title: Parents of toddler with serious medical conditions plead with province for COVID-19 vaccine
description: Parents with children who have serious medical conditions say they want to get a vaccine so they can protect their kids from a potentially fatal COVID-19 infection — but in Manitoba, family caregivers under 40 don't currently qualify.

title: U.S. to resume use of Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine | CBC News
description: The United States will resume use of Johnson & Johnson's COVID-19 vaccine, top health regulators said on Friday, ending a 10-day pause to investigate the vaccine's link to extremely rare but potentially deadly blood clots.

title: How one COVID-19 case is shutting down a small town of 2,400 people | CBC News
description: The township of Black River-Matheson has declared an emergency, under the Ontario Emergency Management and Civil Protection Act, as a significant number of town staff are currently in self-isolation.

title: Saskatchewan's use of remand and handling of COVID-19 in correctional centres | CBC News
description: What's it like to be an inmate in a Saskatchewan correctional centre during a pandemic? We heard from Cory Cardinal, founder of Inmates for Humane Conditions who spoke about his own recent experience in the Saskatoon Correctional Centre, we talked to Pierre Hawkins from John Howard Society about the use of remand in Sask. and why it's used so frequently, we spoke to Julie Paul, whose son contracted COVID-19 while on remand at the Regina Correctional Centre and we heard from a representative of the correctional workers union.

title: Łutselk'e closes school, warns against travel, following COVID-19 cases in Yellowknife | CBC News
description: The community’s leadership says members are not to travel to Yellowknife by air or by snowmobile, and that non-community members are not to travel into Łutselk'e until further notice.

title: 8 new COVID-19 cases, no deaths: OPH | CBC News
description: Although Ottawa Public Health reported eight new COVID-19 cases Sunday, no new deaths from the virus were recorded.

title: CHART | Tracking Ontario COVID-19 cases | CBC News
description: Ontario's COVID-19 case reports, over time in 2020.

title: Your COVID-19 questions answered by QEH's Dr. Trevor Jain
description: Should people with bad asthma wear masks? How do you know that you're recovered from COVID-19? Your questions answered by the QEH's Dr. Trevor Jain, who joins CBC News: Compass host Louise Martin for our monthly health segment.

title: COVID-19 variants found in Lambton County school outbreak | CBC News
description: The outbreak at Brooke Central Public School was declared Wednesday after six people tested positive for COVID-19.

title: East Coast Music Awards 2021 goes virtual over COVID-19 concerns in Nova Scotia | CBC News
description: The East Coast Music Awards announced that all in-person events planned for May 5 to 9 in Sydney, N.S., will be held virtually because of COVID-19 concerns.

title: Third COVID-19 death linked to outbreak at Olymel meatpacking plant in Red Deer | CBC News
description: Alberta reported 356 new cases of COVID-19 on Friday and three more deaths from the illness, the lowest number of COVID-19 deaths reported by the province in a single day in months.

title: Waste not, want not: Montana tribe provides COVID-19 vaccinations at border crossing | CBC News
description: A long line of cars was backed up at the Carway border crossing in southern Alberta this week as First Nations members and others took advantage of free COVID-19 vaccinations from the Blackfeet Tribe in Montana.

title: Locals say Alberta MLAs who spoke out against tougher COVID-19 measures didn't consult them
description: Find out how some officials and residents in ridings with MLAs who criticized COVID restrictions reacted after hearing concerns raised about COVID measures.

title: Alberta to open COVID-19 vaccination clinic at Cargill meat-packing plant | CBC News
description: Alberta plans to open COVID-19 vaccination clinics at meat-packing plants across the province as early as April 20 or sooner, starting with a pilot project at the Cargill operation near High River.

title: New COVID-19 vaccine appointments open up in Ottawa for residents 70 and older | CBC News
description: A slew of new COVID-19 vaccine appointments have opened up in Ottawa and the Eastern Ontario Health Unit following the delivery of new batches of vaccine to those regions.

title: New COVID-19 vaccine appointments open up in Ottawa for residents 70 and older | CBC News
description: A slew of new COVID-19 vaccine appointments have opened up in Ottawa and the Eastern Ontario Health Unit following the delivery of new batches of vaccine to those regions.

title: How much of a game changer is the Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine?
description: Doctors answer questions about the newly approved Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine and what it could mean for Canada’s rollout.

title: COVID-19 on P.E.I.: What's happening Tuesday, Feb. 2 | CBC News
description: Storm cancels regular COVID-19 briefing, and province changes law to allow pharmacists to administer COVID-19 shots.

title: Commercial rent relief program opens but business owners worry it won't help
description: The federal government's commercial rent relief program opened for applications Monday, but a recent survey shows many business owners worry it won't help them. Power & Politics speaks to Small Business Minister Mary Ng about the program.

title: What you need to know about COVID-19 in B.C. for Feb. 24 | CBC News
description: B.C. is preparing to ramp up its COVID-19 immunization program, bringing more health professionals into the workforce and planning to begin mass vaccination clinics in April.

title: Class dismissed at Windsor Catholic high school following positive COVID-19 case | CBC News
description: A class at a Windsor Catholic high school was dismissed Friday following a positive COVID-19 case in a student.

title: Ontario reports 210 new COVID-19 cases as more adults now eligible for an accelerated 2nd vaccine | CBC News
description: Ontario reported another 210 cases of COVID-19 on Monday, the fewest on a single day since mid-September, as all adults in the province who got a first shot of an mRNA vaccine were able to try to book an appointment for an accelerated second dose.

title: Concerns emerge over accessibility of Canada's COVID-19 app
description: Users who download the app are alerted if they come into contact with someone who has tested positive for the coronavirus — if that person also has the app. Some say technical requirements of the app can be a barrier.

title: Variant of concern COVID-19 cases shuts down 2 Sudbury schools | CBC News
description: Public Health Sudbury and Districts says two Sudbury schools have been dismissed after COVID-19 cases that screened positive for variants of concern were detected.

title: What you need to know about COVID-19 in B.C. for Feb. 26 | CBC News
description: There's no end in sight for the current rules banning all social gatherings in B.C., as officials warn of "potential for rapid growth" in the province's caseload.

title: COVID-19 on P.E.I.: What's happening Friday, Feb. 26 | CBC News
description: With six new cases in the past 48 hours, public health officials on P.E.I. are asking all young people 14-29 in the Summerside area to get tested for COVID-19, even if they don't have any symptoms.

title: What you need to know about COVID-19 in Ottawa on Saturday, April 17 | CBC News
description: Here's CBC Ottawa's latest roundup of key updates during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Concerns emerge over accessibility of Canada's COVID-19 app
description: Users who download the app are alerted if they come into contact with someone who has tested positive for the coronavirus — if that person also has the app. Some say technical requirements of the app can be a barrier.

title: Pine Creek First Nation declares local state of emergency due to COVID-19 outbreak | CBC News
description: A First Nation in western Manitoba has declared a local state of emergency in response to a COVID-19 outbreak.

title: 8th COVID-19-related death reported in Manitoba | CBC News
description: Another person who had COVID-19 has died in Manitoba, bringing the total number of deaths related to the disease in the province to eight.

title: Frustration grows among B.C. seniors over lack of COVID-19 vaccine information | CBC News
description: Seniors advocates say lack of details about vaccine rollout, coupled with technological and language barriers, are creating anxiety.

title: Canadian living in U.S. COVID-19 hotspot | CBC News
description: Nakina Sankar Gravier is originally from Winnipeg, but is now living in Florida full time. There are at least 291,000 cases of COVID-19 in Florida and more than 4,400 deaths.

title: Canadians warned about COVID-19 overconfidence on long weekend
description: Canadian health officials continue to warn people not to be overconfident about Canada's success in containing COVID-19, especially on holiday long weekends.

title: Toronto's Caribbean community keep Carnival alive despite COVID-19
description: For the first time in 53 years, the Toronto Caribbean Carnival, previously known as Caribana, couldn't be its usual vibrant, multi-day festival self. But the community found ways to keep the celebrations going.
